timeline.bodyText: Data this large should not be stored in the code. Please put this data in a file and load it at runtime.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: @cpmeister I need some help with this; I would be happy to move the data into a file; but I need to know what path the file should be in, so as to ensure it is properly handled by GitHub, your MVN build environment, and the automated JUnit tests.
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: Ok. I think I figured it out.
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.bodyText:
Ok, instead of using instanceof to do your null check, I suggest instead to just change the map type to
private final Map<ThingUID, @Nullable ServiceRegistration<?>> discos = new HashMap<>();
timeline.author: cpmeister
cpmeister
cpmeister
cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
If you want another way around the null checker map issue

Personally I was quite happy using instanceof -- your suggestion to use contains() followed by get() would work, but it has a performance penalty, I think.
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText:
There is a performance hit, but it would be minimal. Personally, I prefer just making the map value nullable. I was just showing here one of the many ways you can work around the null checker's poor handling of Map classes.
But at the very least, please don't use instanceof  for your null checks. It makes the code very misleading to read.
